thread.title: RETAIL: FBI calls for vigilance in EMV credit card use
thread.title_full: RETAIL: FBI calls for vigilance in EMV credit card use - Press Enterprise

author: FIELDING BUCK
title: RETAIL: FBI calls for vigilance in EMV credit card use
text:
BY FIELDING BUCK / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 9, 2015 Updated: 4:00 p.m. RETAIL: FBI calls for vigilance in EMV credit card use Print Photo Share Pin It More Galleries ADVERTISEMENT Chips appear as barely noticeable silver rectangles on credit and debit cards. EMV FORUM , COURTESY OF EMV FORUM Related article » Chip-enabled credit cards are safer than magnetic strip credit cards, but the FBI is warning merchants to remain vigilant against fraud.
The cards -- called EMV for Europay, Mastercard and Visa -- are the new standard for credit card security, but have vulnerabilities that include the ability to use stolen cards in phone and online purchases.
In a news release, the FBI recommends requiring personal identification numbers (PINs) be used instead of signatures in chip card purchases.
The National Retail Federation endorsed the FBI’s warning.
Oct. 1 was the deadline for merchants to adopt chip-enabled card readers or assume liability for fraudulant purchases, but many Inland merchants are still using magnetic swipe devices.
Chip-enabled cards continue to be made with magnetic strips, another way they are vulnerable to fraud, according to the FBI.
